text: [Music]
all right today I have the pleasure of
doing an early beta review for GOG
galaxy 2.0 the upcoming store front
slash launcher from CD Projekt that is
designed to link all of your existing PC
libraries in one convenient place before
we get to that however I want to take a
couple of minutes to talk about our
video sponsor called Amino the process
of determining sponsors is fairly
complex if it would affect objectivity
or impact the quality of the video
material itself well that's obviously
not going to work but Amino rather than
being something that ties to the games
industry specifically is a framework for
social communities and groups before
finalizing the partnership I asked the
upper-echelon community if they had any
feedback on Amino and the responses I
got were extremely positive so I'm
pleased to work with Amino as a channel
sponsor their communities for tons of
different subjects from gaming news to
artwork history and everything in
between there is also a new type of
content called aminos stories that I
will be posting which operate as a sort
of bullet point of video series to check
out my stories and the material of other
creators on Amino just search
upper-echelon gamers and find my global
profile as this video goes live on
YouTube the story version will go live
on Amino as well thank you again to
Amino for partnering with the channel
it's a great social space with a lot of
different really cool communities that
are very active it's been a pleasure
working with them and using the platform
but now on to the actual video GOG
galaxy 2.0 is at its core a bridge
between launchers recently in the games
industry there's been a growing amount
of interest in first party digital
storefronts and the result is that PC
users now have to utilize multiple
different platforms to play all of their
games where once there was really only
steam now there is the epic store origin
you play battlenet Bethesda launcher and
more because of the emphasis on
exclusivity that some of these launchers
prioritize whether it be first party
exclusives developed in-house like what
origin does or offering cash to
developers in order to force users to
use their shitty little platform like
what epic does the end result is the
same different games different launchers
different friends lists integrations and
overall it is becoming rather messy and
inconvenient GOG galaxy 2.0 looks to
solve this problem and from what I've
seen so far it has the framework to do
an excellent job of it I was invited to
join the private beta and it's already
become my primary launcher for most of
the games that I play within a few
minutes I have been able to link steam
the epic store you play and my xbox live
account since those are what I primarily
use but there are a few more
integrations already offered like
PlayStation Network origin and battlenet
this is by no means the entire list of
potential launchers but it's already
quite large for a beta version and the
biggest hurdle by far will be for CD
Projekt to form relationships with these
competing publishers thus allowing for
all remaining features to integrate
fully as it stands even with just the
current selection it is already a large
step forward for a lot of gamers so any
additional partnerships that they can
negotiate will be of great benefit but I
already see the link to launch or
function for their immediate roster as a
powerful motivating factor now it's
important to understand what the
function actually is because I've seen a
lot of misconceptions recently
once you have linked your Steam or epic
account or whatever launcher it may be -
GOG galaxy you are able to launch your
games through GOG without opening and
actively using the other storefront
however this does not fully circumvent
those other storefronts for every
activity if you want to buy a game that
is exclusive to say the epic store you
will need to log into the epic store and
purchase the game there once that is
done however you can import it to GOG
galaxy and not be forced to use the epic
store regularly which is a plus but not
quite what some players imagined it to
be now in the future if CD Projekt were
able to negotiate the option it may be
possible to buy games from other store
fronts directly through GOG galaxy but
even in such an instance the purchase
would still be in direct support of
those alternative platforms GOG galaxy
is a convenience tool not a full-on
replacement of the existing stores if
GOG galaxy could enable a central
storefront linked to all existing
launchers it could have tremendous user
appeal imagine being able to compare
side-by-side all the different store
prices for a game you're interested in
and then picking the one that best fits
your needs or has the lowest price
platform discounts don't always coincide
so a game that is $60 on one storefront
might be 40 temporarily on another
though the occurrence is rare with the
heavy emphasis on exclusivity nowadays
but it can happen and in such a case GOG
galaxy would allow a user to see that
side by side if they can manage to form
the partnerships at the moment I can't
find any indication towards this being
an intended feature and since GOG galaxy
is itself a competing store front I
would expect there to be a fair amount
of friction when it comes to a service
like that but when constructing a
central game library a feature that
beneficial should at least be discussed
because as interest grows in the
storefront
CD Projekt might be able to obtain
enough leverage in order to work towards
a feature that significant next is your
friends list as it stands this is an
area where galaxy is a lot more to build
the ultimate mission is to have one
central game library with one central
friends list alongside that conveniently
links everything together but unlike the
current game integration roster the
friends list feature is far less
developed as far as I can tell the only
integration so far is Facebook which if
we're being honest is a fairly
insignificant platform to link for a lot
of gamers but if progress can be made on
that front which I have no doubt it will
over time then the mission of developing
galaxies into a fully functional hub by
itself will gather serious momentum when
examining your game library it is mostly
well polished the majority of games have
pre-selected cover art and even when
they do not have that artwork you can
manually go in and set your own if you
desire to do so when actually launching
a game it's hit or miss however the
process of updating still takes place
through the game's initial storefront
not through Gog and it's not possible to
completely circumvent launching that
original platform so if there are
updates required or if you fully logged
out of the game's primary platform
launching through GOG galaxy will open
up that second sore front which can be
really annoying and somewhat slow now we
arrived at privacy this is where GOG
galaxy truly starts to shine user data
in the modern tech industry is valuable
it can be harvested for analytical
purposes catalogued for marketing
reasons or in some cases outright sold
to the highest bidder
CD Projekt and GOG have a very simple
and precise approach to this concept
their stance is it's your data you are
in control of it when you decide to drop
the service uninstall or sever
connections to the storefront all of
your data is immediately deleted from
all GOG servers this is a far cry from
how its competition store fronts like
epic games have been approaching the
issue the emphasis on consumer data
privacy is refreshing it is appreciated
and it is important for helping to
maintain the excellent reputation the CD
project has been able to cultivate with
the widespread gaming community in its
current form GOG galaxy 2.0 is clearly
an early stage version of what it will
eventually become but the main benefit
that I see and the likely goal overall
is to bring new players onto the
platform where they are then able to
purchase games direct from GOG
themselves as opposed to sticking with
their previous storefronts there are
numerous different benefits to buying on
over other competing launchers but none
larger than their approach to DRM GOG
has a very pointed policy which I have
discussed in the past in previous videos
called f ck DRM in which they outlined
the stance that your games are exactly
that your games and they do not intend
to interfere with your ability to
download the game client and launch it
at your own convenience much like their
privacy approach
CD Projekt makes every effort to build
their services around the consumer and
to the benefit of their player base this
anti DRM or digital rights management
approach while vastly beneficial to
players is perceived as detrimental by
certain developers or publishers the
issue of internet piracy is a
complicated one and some developers
believe that publishing their game or
updating it fully on GOG may result in
an increased rate of their game being
illegally pirated to me though I have no
concrete data or evidence to support
these assumptions that seems entirely
incorrect consumers often resort to
piracy as an effort to circumvent
predatory practices or as a mechanism to
express discontent The Epoch store for
instance is cultivating one of the worst
reputations in gaming history
they are despised reviled and hated
mostly as a result of Tim Sweeney and
his totally ignorant approach to
customer relations which leads to a huge
influx in the number of users that are
willing to pirate products that made
backroom deals with epic CD Projekt is
on the opposite end of that spectrum I
know a great many players and this is
anecdotal evidence to be sure but I do
consider myself to have a fairly
wide-ranging community from which to
gather feedback I know a large number of
players who are fully willing and
enthusiastic even about buying a product
from CD Projekt and GOG they are glad to
give their money to one of the only
companies that they perceive to truly
have their best interests at heart
so when facing the claim of increased
piracy as a result of laxer DRM from GOG
I would steadfastly claim that that is
in fact the opposite of what is true GOG
galaxy 2.0 succeeds in its primary goal
of becoming a central library for your
games there are a few libraries which
have yet to be integrated such as
Nintendo or Bethesda but CD Projekt have
stated that they are actively working on
expanding their relationships and adding
more partners galaxy does not eliminate
the need for other launchers entirely
they must still be installed and running
and up-to-date for galaxies to tap into
them but it does allow for you to view
your entire library under one central
roof with
comprehensive analytics filters and
sorting capabilities the friendslist is
at a very early stage but it is
eventually intended to link all of your
social groups together in one place
which might be one of the greatest
benefits of all and although there are
no confirmed plans to add store
integrations that bypass the alternative
launchers entirely such as steam or the
epic store if the platform can gain
enough momentum and popularity among PC
gamers CD projects ability to expand on
what the service offers will increase
right alongside it one last point of
note here is the receptivity towards
Community Development a lot of platforms
take a very closed off approach nowadays
but CD Projekt in typical fashion is
allowing the community to develop and
post integrations that will be available
for download by everyone else I'm no
expert on this craft but in my
experience whenever a company opens up
their product or their game to the
creativity of their fan base wonderful
unexpected and very impressive things
happen so all things considered GOG
galaxy is already my primary game
library tool and I'm very enthusiastic
about watching it grow and evolve over
time that's it for today though there
are a bunch of links down below there is
the amino story of this upload which
will be live as well if you want to
check it out or become a channel member
or a bunch of other stuff but I'll cut
it there and stop rambling as always
thank you all for watching and have a
nice night
[Music]
